document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

5A646869DDDD443AAA3B571CEFED332B.description:
Work with the weaving loom frequently because, “it’s
just like my Abuela’s.”

D8EC5B7A054542D288551AC519781C61.description:
Describe why they like to play with the egg shakers (or
another favorite instrument).

0167902A0F2C49D9BA8D4984070648D3.description: Tell a friend they like their drawing.

56E2F43F33F3426AA87184B6B4F306FF.description:
Tell about their preferences in colors and textures, such
as saying that they want to play with the green plastic
blocks and not the blue ones.

0CE988AA4B2549DE9B11093374DC1488.description:
Move and dance to describe their own feelings, or a feeling/
idea from a story.

8C1F3D48547B4DD2913E083425015D4C.description:
Show their thoughts, ideas, and feelings through multiple art
forms, such as combining drawing with writing to express an
idea or draw or paint symbols on a clay formation.

D03590E0B9B04B298A2B17672F7A642D.description: Create a book of pictures that tell a story.

279E7E7614AE49989A23949F251F7AA6.description:
Mimic the sound of a musical instrument with their voice,
such as making high-pitched noises to match a triangle, or
low thumping sounds to match a drum.

6E072AAEDA2B430BBC6FCB2E4B6748B8.description:
Move ribbons or scarves in time with the music when
dancing to a song that switches from fast to slow, or slow to
fast.

ADDB634ED9B54A2D97B98F646D4EB869.description:
Compare and identify the differences between a slow song
and a fast one, or a quiet song and an upbeat one.

F57B1441566443CE9C745AE8DAFDFD7A.description: Move their body in ways that match the mood of a song.

F6FA1734581C4FB491A28C2D6D83E930.description:
Draw a picture and describe or dictate to a familiar adult
what the picture is showing.

50BBA541482A4ED0BD95D111682B340B.description:
Use drawings (including scribbles) to tell a story or describe
a concept (such as showing who is part of their family).

ED4DA324DD29465C92815C59EBD5F36A.description: Sing a silly song and laugh.

9403671E4C4841D691C540981A5169A3.description:
Experiment with different instruments to match the sounds in
a song.

1D1FDC12227D4D0C884BEBD9F4635848.description:
Experiment with a variety of instruments and recognize their
differing sounds.

8B6EDB65387B4FFCAC4DA818430B7103.description:
Tap on a drum, a table, and a cardboard box to hear the
different sounds.

BD3F4389EBF3404C8F7DC19F4B70D361.description:
Explore different musical instruments, such as bells,
xylophones, and maracas.

BB86B509AC7348858795F1B6AE72D298.description:
Bang on a drum or pot to make loud noises and show
frustration—or delight.

99A5D4CA602549958B99D26041D24E20.description:
Point out the differences in color or mood (happy, sad)
between two pictures.

84942A69F9D148399D60A378DFD3CE45.description:
Explore, recognize, and respond to similarities and differences between works of art, and
the emotions, moods, situations, and cultures being expressed.

E420F06B0B564837AD8545EDBED1EFE6.description: Children develop preferences and appreciation for the arts.

D22A1B22828C4DC08C5FF87155A7A4C7.description:
Focus on a single work for longer periods of time, such as sessions over 30
minutes, returning later in the day, and/or working over multiple days.

D14CF49072BC4A6F9C981B106F8CF493.description: Add details to their work and revise when necessary.

0C9D38BC57004C4F90305DB30AC94EF3.description:
Plan a creation, saying, “I’m going to paint a picture of my cat. She has
brown stripes and a white belly.”

A03948C5C17A4B6B953970F25F50E60E.description: Use a variety of media (paint, text, music, etc.) to express themselves.

AF61FAD782524D7B9D512C2C496E9561.description:
Ask questions about a prompt to “Draw and write about your day” to clarify if it
should only be about school-time or if they can draw their morning routine too.

AD4B228FF98F497A86F5B551488BBDAA.description: Create intentional designs in their work.

FEDCDADEBD5F4B529ADCF4EA37ABA68A.description: When asked, describe their plan for a drawing or painting.

554BE7F641E34E9D8A2BBCDDED5F0925.description: With and without prompting, communicate their ideas through the arts.

1702527244654BA9B6F45DAB95D64DFD.description: Draw straight and curved lines to create pictures.

DB96AB0BFD9C45C9A1C8D2166949535F.description:
Follow along with appropriate body movements during “Head Shoulders
Knees and Toes.”

F5B62B11A8A340CB9EAB85E726B73949.description: With prompting, express their ideas through the arts.

DAA4E4E23B5243C98AE0E9E9B88A22F4.description: Plan and create works of art with increasing intentionality and detail.

B1688F94CEBF4B73A0FBD4F007807A87.description:
Experiment with changing the pressure they use on their crayons or colored
pencils to make dark and light shades.

42FEE3AD3DD346E491515DF78512C0DD.description: Combine two colors of paint to get the shade they want.

DFC329ABCA88417887DF3B19B1A3DDEE.description: Use terms like sculpture, sketch, and melody to describe art, sometimes.

AC8ADC403BEF491F9BD8CCB618E94B33.description:
Use creative tools with noticeable control as they create artwork with some
detail and intentional color choices.

6482B7EB00A440559B19CAC3C1F41C57.description: Match the beat of a song when playing an instrument along with music.

8699F80940B34208A7C21561AC237388.description: Use tissue paper, construction paper, and glitter glue to make a collage.

1CC79988A98D427BB4362FBAD598CF40.description:
Use whatever materials are on hand (blocks, paint, playdough,
manipulatives) to create something new.

F198A63B9E3F47BE9F957327A3368986.description:
Experiment with the angles they can hold a crayon or marker to make
different kinds of marks.

21AEF47EE2EE41CDBF53A4F3B2296CC1.description: Use cookie cutters and rollers to shape playdough.

B0A8B24831F743D3A74E05F6A198951A.description: Repeat part of a song they have just heard for the first time.

DC2A9E457C7741D6ACF54C3AC6B3C72A.description: Use terms like collage, rhythm, and watercolor to describe art, sometimes.

662F01EC099F48C9989A8AEE8222F61C.description: Point to a jar of paint or basket of crayons and ask to use them.

064900EFC72244D1AFDA551293AC3F6A.description: Use terms like volume, beat, and shadow to describe art, sometimes.

A944B4B8CE7D40BA86FD35B4F8B1761F.description:
With support, use tongue depressors to make bunny ears in a ball of
playdough.

11207BA2741349B58658D6F53BB2156E.description: Make different sounds with their voice (loud/soft, high/low).

4023BFBD8C4948A99F4A20D9B47E6ABE.description: Use props like ribbon sticks, scarves, and dolls while dancing to music.

4F83DA7ABE8A4BDB9F77F50B42FC8B60.description: Make “pizza” out of playdough and pretend to eat it during imaginative play.

1919B3A5B5D14DC18BE50ECA98B3380C.description: Use a towel as a blanket to “tuck in” a doll for bedtime.

C5919F5B480F4354A0BC04E228D154BB.description:
Explore, use, and begin to use artistic vocabulary to describe the tools, mediums, and components
of the arts.

BA0928ABB35044D3ACDD4207BD5C26A8.description:
Use fine motor skills to pinch, push, and form playdough into the shape they
want.

29FC42B4A624492DBD96F047F7824B75.description: Match the beat of a song when playing an instrument along with music.

3D10052C80DE4323824A135B3330429E.description:
Imitate a familiar adult’s movements when trying to learn a new dance, most
of the time.

5CDAB248FEA841039E3F487A09536A2C.description:
Show more control in making intentional marks, such as straight and curved
lines.

37C1670C915E4D1CA54A3B2D41E1883E.description:
Use scissors with more precision, cutting along dotted or folded lines, most
of the time.

9E8C403555174D0EB658D2200E982989.description: Draw and combine shapes into more complex figures.

2333A0A1B2684F8FB6E9457BA73C3258.description:
Match and repeat a rhythm demonstrated by a familiar adult, such as
stomping their feet back and forth (left-right, left-right) four times.

2D2870541DCE40389D66A28A478C4A5F.description: Dance to the (approximate) beat of different kinds of music, most of the time.

173E256ABBBA40FEA799C12AE23FEF52.description: Draw straight and curved lines to create pictures.

408FEF4342284FBDBBC645CCF20E10E9.description: Attempt to mimic a familiar adult’s clapping rhythm.

21484FCEC7B049D28C3FFB88249A5F85.description: Squish and roll playdough into balls and snakes.

D3D6ABE85D6646D3B8B03C8DEF0CF9DB.description:
Play along with songs like “Hokey Pokey” and “Head Shoulders Knees and
Toes.”

DB75BDF15CC74411A59C534E5107580F.description: Explore and develop increasing control over fine motor and large motor movements.

9F4F0F6496114C279F02D4ECFD56C247.description: Children develop the skills that support self-expression through a variety of art forms.

1BD9B4B713B04E7DA141300C95FA5673.description:
Work with other children to decide on the details of a story to tell in
their play, and who will perform each role.

3767C7ACA38F4CCEBF0197B4822AB2DB.description:
Act out familiar stories or characters from books, movies, or
television.

5D9F73AD657A4F6485615002BBA4388E.description:
Explain to other children their ideas or plans for play, such as
describing the roles they want each person to act out.

E2A90831E9EA4E318CBD892CE19527F5.description:
Mimic words and phrases commonly used by familiar adults or
favorite shows.

7DAC0B02259E492490BAD56DB9450D23.description:
Join in cooperative pretend play with other children, passing
dishes around the table during a pretend meal.

0B03F87EBF4941CFAB3780740D05EA4F.description:
Imitate other people’s conversations and interactions during
pretend play, in a similar context to how they heard or experienced
the conversation initially. Often, they will recite memorable words
and phrases.

DF2D752DC6274F2A8539E19449F3557D.description:
Explore roles, express thoughts, and feelings, recreate experiences, and act out stories
through the arts.

47F9F0285CC84C4B90ABE28B95673B08.description:
Extend their pretend play with other children by including more themes,
detail, and storylines, such as turning a pretend meal into a Thanksgiving,
Chinese New Year, or Kwanzaa dinner with cousins, aunts, and uncles.

332114A1FC0847EBB8017FE14380AB2E.description:
Incorporate their home culture into color, texture, and musical choices in
their artwork.

E7EE6296790A46B3993FA3585E30203D.description:
Engage in a discussion with other children to decide which favorite foods
from home will be served during their pretend meal (collaborative pretend
play).

C882D39853EA45F9951F47AACA02513A.description: Show some preference for dolls that look like themselves.

CB2153EF1A344864AE61AA38BA45F827.description:
Wear “dress up” clothes that are similar to those commonly worn by their
family.

205FB7A01F9445CEA8C889103CA38897.description:
Explore and experiment with the arts through the lens of their personal cultural context and that of
others.

8FC1C8A99B964DE0BDA7D55C5D09EF9D.description:
Use fine motor skills to pinch, push, and form playdough into the shape they
want.

FF2C7B8D23B54C5DBFFD43C4EBB3463F.description:
Invent their own songs – sometimes just music and sometimes also with
lyrics.

4B38D8D915A4447FAEE8983D089EA26B.description: Contribute to group storytelling and songwriting.

1A49F92725134952A7D53A65A9D62772.description: Draw and combine shapes into more complex figures.

C8D16F63DFDD48AE83D96A1D0F6A3A89.description:
Respond with matching movements when asked to move like a certain
animal (arms out like a bird, hop like a kangaroo, etc.).

8D8EF71CD4B94777BC140666F3A85A66.description: Follow the directions in a movement song.

2856CA07FA8B402EBE2A929444C94455.description: Talk with others about the artwork they have made.

BDFEF1C3DA7949D49B8574FA6997FB29.description: Hum the tune of a familiar or invented song.

62C101757C6F406F847FD3E507A1A495.description:
Display their artwork to a familiar adult, and say, “Take a picture for my
daddy!”

4347E7C5265F4D51A36CAC3807BB0628.description: When prompted, describe what they are creating.

A0479C008435425489D5DF2A39FA2040.description:
Explore and experiment with the arts in increasingly creative ways to express themselves, with
modifications as needed.

1567D7E7933C466F8877E6C860687AE3.description:
Children develop healthy self-concepts through creative self-expression that draws from
their backgrounds, experiences, and identities.
